ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about what the field of anthropology, and learned about how corpoations interact / have interacted with people historically.

I learned a good amount about the form, history and culture of corporations. Specifically we spent a lot of time thinking about different ways to analyze corporations, like thinking through the idea of corporations as people in different historical moments. I learned a lot about corporations themselves, especially the historical arc of their development, and saw the many different ways in which we can think about corporations. (legally, economically, through the people they employ, through their organization, their broader influence on society, etc.) 

I also learned a good amount about sociology and anthropology, like what it means to do this work, how interviews are conducted and compiled, what we can learn from it, etc.
learned how to do ethnography
I learned about the evolution of corporations and how they have evolved over the course of our history.

This class will change the way you understand and critique corporations. I came in expecting the class to be one-dimensionally vicious towards corporations and their role in society, but was surprised with the extremely nuanced view on the corporation that it provides. Critique is well balanced and justified, but not emphasized until the history and development of corporation form is fully fleshed out. I really appreciated this about the course. I am still critical of corporations after the semester (as I believe the course wants you to be) but in a much more complex and meaningful way.
I learned how to think about corporations as more than just profit-making endeavors. I also learned about the basics of ethnography and research at Yale.

This class I was able to gather new insights on how to think about abstract ideas. This class provided me a strong framework for rethinking what it means to have a theory of the world. I get to engage with different modes of analysis in discussion and writing. This class provides an introduction to how cultural anthropology can explain the world around us, the corporation and us.
The corporation as a person!
I learned how to analyze corporation's decisions based on history and economic intuition.

Emphasis on the development of nuanced conceptual understandings with extensive historical contextualization. A major skill is the embrace of this nuance and the analysis of different perspectives on abstract notions.
Deep insight into corporate America, corporate history, demystification of the idea of corporation.
I learned a lot about the legal and social history of corporations. I believe I developed a lot of tools and strengthened my critical thinking from taking this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths included great lectures which were engaging, organized, understandable and good at connecting concepts from previous classes in a narrative arc that shaped the whole semester. The two essays were also pretty good assignments, more creative and engaging than most assignments in lectures.

I really liked some of the readings, although others I liked less, and I often felt like they were too long, especially for a 100-level course. I would say section was often a strength too it's one of the few (maybe only) section I've had in 7 terms at Yale that helped me learn more than I could gain from just reading the text myself. 

I do think sometime the concepts in lecture were a bit obvious or intuitive  to me the course felt much better at developing ideas I already had an awareness of, and less good at really shocking me with a brand new idea or concept. That isn't necessarily a weakness, but I think I was hoping for the latter a bit more.
this course wouldve been great if i was a first year.

Strengths: An interesting course with good readings

Weaknesses: More work than expected

Strengths - This is a class that makes you think, in a really good way. The answers are not laid out for you on a platter. This is due to the fact that 'answers' don't really exist in context of the way the class approaches corporations. The formation of the course results in a very complex understanding of corporations and their role in society. 

Weaknesses - Lectures can lean a little too heavily on readings at times.

The course is a very interesting introduction to corporations. I would have liked a little more information and study of the transformation of the corporate model in the class. Although it is the major transformation of the course, we did not critically analyze it, only suddenly started reading authors talking about "post-Fordism." We had one reading about the transition, but did not critically analyze it so much as take it at face value. For a class that brought a sharp eye to everything, this was an exception.
Super engaging and interesting!
I would have liked if the essays weren't so heavily focused on the readings. Maybe a different type of assignment could be correlated to the readings.

Strengths are the structure; having lectures early in the week and section later in the week is ideal.  A weakness of this course was at times I felt as if the readings covered too many different topics each week. The course could be improved by a more focused reading list, as I think it would be more effective to deeply discuss and understand fewer readings than to only understand a high number of readings to a lesser extent.

The course assignments were great for facilitating learning! I loved the larger time frames for them giving students flexibility. I do wish that the first assignment were shifted up slightly earlier to better pace them out.
This was by far one of my most favorite courses Ive taken at Yale. I took it on a whim and will forever be grateful for the way it taught me to think about corporations and our relation to them.

The lectures brought a new perspective to the readings, which I appreciated. Although I thought they got off topic at times. I also would have preferred the sections to be slightly more structured/rewarding, as I felt that I left section more confused that I was going in. The course was also very broad, and I think it left things too introductory and open-to-interpretation for the essays.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure - it's a medium-workload course that teaches some useful concepts.

Yes I would! It has great lectures, pretty interesting readings and concepts, not too much work and my section at least was actually pretty decent! The writing will take some time, especially the background work in the two essays, and some of the readings seem too long but like any lecture course it's easy to not do them. Some of the readings are quite good though, so I would recommend doing as many as you can!

Prof. Rogers is quite engaging in lecture and really focuses on making the class all about students learning. He was open to feedback and responsive to emails. While the assignments are a good chunk of work, if you take them seriously they are pretty engaging and help you learn. The class is definitely driven by the concepts he develops. 

It's also a great class to get a sense of anthropology/sociology as a discipline, what sort of work it entails and what knowledge it produces. 

The only thing I would change would be reducing the number of pages in some of the readings, and maybe having 2-3 assignments, rather than four.
yes if youre brand new to anthropology at yale. a good intro.
I would recommend it to another student. It's an interesting course and a smaller lecture, just be prepared for a lot of writing for a non-writing class.

ABSOLUTELY!!!! This is really a course that everyone should take. Corporations are a major reality of the world we live in and everyone should get the opportunity to think about them in the way that this course prompts you to
Yes it was great

I would absolutely recommend the course to other students. It is a fascinating look at corporations that you are unlikely to encounter in many other classes at Yale, especially if you are an econ. student. I came in a little skeptical, and I think some healthy skepticism is always good, but the class has so much to offer in terms of new ways of thinking about and examining the ways corporations and people interact in the world.
Yes! Incredible content and really fun.
I'd recommend this course to someone who is interested in the exploitation of certain people and how it correlates to business decisions and strategy.
Yes, I think the class was structured well and certainly was very educational. I would just make sure the student knew that it had a very heavy reading load.
Absolutely!! Incredibly engaging and a must for everyone interested in the intersection of politics, history and economics.

Yes, it was the highlight of my semester. Professor Rodgers was so insightful, entertaining, and knowledgeable. My TA was amazing as well, you can tell that the teaching team genuinely enjoys discussing the class and materials. It was such a joy taking this class.

It depends. I would recommend it for someone who is interested in Sociology or Anthropology and wants to take it for those majors. However, I would not recommend it to upperclassmen or people who want to take it for social science credit.
